column4: This page https://wiki.ubuntu.com/KernelCompileHowto says: "At this point, you need to change your kernel's configuration to statically include your bus, disk, and filesystem drivers." - do you know why this is the case? I never did this in Debian Woody and didn't have problems.
if you didn't do it on woody, you wouldn't have had a bootable kernel
the default woody config included such things statically
But not on Hoary? Above that warning it says to copy the .config from /boot to the compile directory and that was sufficient for Woody
why are you compiling a kernel anyway?
I am trying to debug a device driver, so want to make some changes to it
Ubuntu would appear to be different. The .boot/config... in Hoary has IDE as a module, whereas in Woody it is static
yes, woody was from 2002
sarge is the same as hoary
if you know how to debug a driver, presumably you know how to configure a kernel, so just go from scratch
I could, but I haven't compiled one with Ubuntu and just installed it yesterday so am looking for the easiest option
it's identical to every other os
this is not between "woody and hoary" it's between "2002 and the modern world".  everyone is doing initrd now
So if I use an initrd, I don't need to compile in bus/disk/filesystem? That howto implies that it does, which confused me
An initrd is a pain in the ass?
yes
In what way, I haven't had any problems in the past, and have used it because it was the Woody default
no, initrds are not the default on woody
Isn't kernel-image built with a initrd  - I certainly have an initrd from the default kernel lying around?
kernel-image, yes, but the default kernel is not from a kernel-image package
Thanks for your help
